conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine when objects are farthest apart.
Graph shows curves for objects A and B with velocity on vertical axis and time on horizontal axis.
At time t = 0, both objects start from the same location with the same initial velocity v0.
Relative speed is the absolute difference of velocities |vA(t) - vB(t)|.
Distance increases when relative speed is positive, decreases when negative.
Red lines are tangent to velocity curves at specific points.
Identify tangent points to understand when relative speed changes direction.
Tangent lines intersect curves at times t1, t2, t3, and t4.
Between t = 0 and t1, both objects move in the same direction with decreasing velocities.
At t = t1, object B starts moving faster than object A.
Between t1 and t2, object B continues to move faster than object A.
At t = t2, object A starts moving faster than object B.
Between t2 and t3, object A continues to move faster than object B.
At t = t3, object B starts moving faster than object A again.
Between t3 and t4, object B continues to move faster than object A.
Maximum distance occurs when relative speed is at its maximum.
Relative speed is maximum at t = t2.
